snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appeared to be attacking the Kurdish leadership for its insistence on retaining the ground Kurds took in northern Iraq after the fall of Mosul to Sunni militants.
abstract: Iraq’s Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki accuses Kurds of aiding Sunni militants, even as sectarian tensions appears to be rising with the discovery of 50 bodies, blindfolded, bound and shot about 50 miles south of Baghdad; part of Maliki's anger is over persistent demand for Kurdish independence, even as Iraq is in the midst of trying to form a new government.

byline.contributor: Marwa Salman contributed reporting from Baghdad, and employees of The New York Times from Kirkuk, Iraq, and Hilla, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appeared to be attacking the Kurdish leadership for its insistence on retaining the ground Kurds took in northern Iraq after the fall of Mosul to Sunni militants.

headline.main: Iraqi Premier Blames Kurds for Advances by Militants
headline.print_headline: Iraqi Premier Blames Kurds for Advances by Militants

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
